article:
The 'soul', in many mythological, religious, philosophical, and psychological
traditions, is the incorporeal and, in many conceptions, immortal essence of a
person, living thing, or object. "soul."EncyclopÃ¦dia Britannica. 2010.
EncyclopÃ¦dia Britannica 2006 CD. 13 July 2010. According to some religions
(including the Abrahamic religions in most of their forms), soulsâor at least
immortal souls capable of union with the divine Union with the divine may
include several concepts including Salvation, Theosis, Henosis, Moksha
etc âbelong only to human beings. For example, the Catholic theologian
Thomas Aquinas attributed "soul" (anima) to all organisms but taught that only
human souls are immortal. Peter Eardley and Carl Still, Aquinas: A Guide for
the Perplexed (London: Continuum, 2010), pp. 34â35  Other religions (most notably Jainism) teach that
all biological organisms have souls, and others further still that non-
biological entities (such as rivers and mountains) possess souls. This latter
belief is called animism. [http://www.bartleby.com/65/so/soul.html "Soul"],
The Columbia Encyclopedia, Sixth Edition. 2001â07. Retrieved 12 November
2008. Anima mundi and the Dharmic Ätman are concepts of a "world soul."

Soul can function as a synonym for [[spirit]], [[mind]], [[psyche
(psychology)|psyche]] or [[Self (spirituality)|self]]. [http://www.britanni-
ca.com/EBchecked/topic/555149/soul "Soul",] EncyclopÃ¦dia Britannica. 2008.
Retrieved 12 November 2008.
